comments.text: I just recently purchased an ASRock Radeon RX 9070 XT, upgrading from my trusty GTX 1070, and man, what a huge upgrade it's been! I have nothing bad to say about my GTX 1070 because I've had that card since 2018, I believe, and it has seen me through all my games, and it's just now started giving me issues with the higher-end AAA games. I'm very happy with my RX 9070 XT, and I got it for $700, so considering the current prices of the RTX 5070 Ti, I'm very happy with it and don't regret trying AMD.
comments.author: @andrewramirez3107

comments.text:
Even in Japan, the price advantage of the 9070XT is disappearing. In this country, Palit has created a sales channel where distributors and retailers are the same, so the 5070Ti GamingPro is being sold for $63 less than the MSRP. The price dropped by $139 in two months.This is exactly the same price as the Red Devil 9070 XT now. I needed a GPU immediately so I bought the Red Devil shortly after it was released, but if the Palit GP had been available for the same price at the time, I probably would have bought it instead. 
After switching to Red, I realized how great the RTX VSR is. Red doesn't have the same features, so I can't upscale my streaming videos beautifully. There is a feature called video upscaling, but it's just garbage and completely unusable, which shocked me. 
NITRO+ and Taichi are $90 more expensive than Red Devil, and TUF is even more expensive. The lower model is also only $70 cheaper than the RD&GP, so it doesn't feel like a good deal at all. In my country, only the lower model of 9070XT can be purchased in physical stores. It's hard to find them online. The higher end models are almost never available in stores or online. Retailers know that even if they purchase in bulk, they will end up with a mountain of inventory and will not be able to cope with price fluctuations, which will result in losses, so they are cautious and only sell small amounts at a time. I think that's the right decision. Radeon is still far behind GeForce, so if they don't lower their prices quickly, they'll lose a lot of market share. Red's momentum was only at first.
comments.author: @銀河光芒

comments.text: I think the price advantage only happen in the west. In my country as well, it's much more common to find Nvidia card with retailers having little stock for AMD. This is turn causing the Nvidia cards to be sold at or lower than MSRP (except for certain AIB that offers premium features) while price for AMD cards are jacked up.

comments.text:
I have spent 30 hours this weekend looking to buy a new video card and new system because of tariffs. Some of you think that prices will come down, but I think you are wrong. I initially found nothing available except for some refurbished 4080's and either a RX 7900 XTX Nitro+ or an Asrock for 1100USD and 1000USD respectively. I could not find any RX 9070 XT's. There were RX 7900's but that is even worse. I was about to pull the trigger and get the Nitro+ room heater when I suddenly found an Asus Tuf RTX 5700 Ti OC for 1100. I had spent many hours researching the Radeon's and so I then I researched the Ti. It was a no brainer since it was only 100 more than MSRP from Asus and fully supports DLSS. I would have bought a 9070 had one been available for 900 or less. They are not shipping cards to the US because video cards are NOT excluded from the Tariff which is either 125% or 145%, I forget which. I wish AMD and their vendors had built and shipped sufficient supply because I really don't like Nividia anymore as they no longer care about us gamers any more. I will not wait until the prices increase to the point I can't buy one. If I am out a couple hundred, that is better than never getting one. I've spent 3K and I haven't even bought a monitor yet. I am not waiting until it costs 7K+ for what I just purchased because all of this stuff is made in China. No one is addressing this in their video's. Buyer beware.

Maybe I should have gotten the XTX to help with my heating bill...

comments.text:
Appreciate all the benchmarking, that had to take forever.  And I love AMD, I use their processors exclusively and have only used AMD/ATI as my GPUs.

That said, not to discount the 9070XT, but if you were to drop the worst two games for each card, there would be a very big difference in peformance swinging towards the 5070 Ti.  It's painfully obvious that Rocket League is an extreme outlier, with nearly double the difference of the next game.  In an actual statistical analysis, that would be thrown out as it's well outside the standard deviation.  You can't say the same of ACC, as there are 3 other games which see similar performance differences and it's well within variance.  That 5% difference is propped up by a single game where something very different than card performance is going on.  Without that one title there is a really big gap that cannot be ignored, and you can easily see just by looking at the volume of the bars on the chart that the performance difference is much bigger - at least double the volume in favor of Nvidia.  And that's not taking into account that DLSS is a bit better, turning on RT expands the gap even more, and that any future games/apps with AI tasks will be handled far better by the 5070 Ti.  AMD did good here, but I see website after website trying to prop them up when their data says differently.  And I get it, I'd love to see some more competition.  But the reason for hyping AMD is always the same - more competition to bring Nvidia's cards down in price so we can buy one of those as they are clearly superior.

The math on this is a bit skewed unintentionally in favor of the 9070 XT. For example, in the results for The Riftbreaker, the 5070 Ti is 31% faster at 4k, but it's presented as the XT being 24% slower since you're basing off of XT performance. But in Rocket League, you don't say the 5070 Ti is 29% slower, you say the XT is 41% faster.

It's skewing the results towards the XT in a significant way and I'd suggest only using a '% faster' metric across the board.

comments.text: So the AMD GPU has a 12% better price-performance ratio. But the 5070 Ti offers slightly better DLSS with many games, especially on older upscaling versions. It has better FG, slightly more overclocking potential (for once), better RT, and better DDR, which is perhaps insignificant and already included in the FPS comparison. However, I've watched many reviews showing significantly lower VRAM consumption for the NVIDIA card (I think this is more likely to be driver-related than a much better DDR7 usage, but if it's driver-related, then the NVIDIA GPU will probably benefit more from future driver updates...). All of this matters, I think the price/value ratio between these two cards is so close that there isn't even a slight winner. Better to choose the best deal for one or the other. I think AMD is extremely lucky that NVIDIA missed its launch so badly. If the 9070 XT had only 20GB of VRAM, it would be a clear winner in my opinion. Because the AMD card would have an advantage over Nvidia better softwares and that is a better Future.

comments.text:
So the sum total of this was we should have bought a 4070 Ti Super, 4080 Super or 7900 XT/XTX last October, got 6 months more gameplay and spent less money?

That's not exactly inspiring anyone. 

I held on for a 9070 XT, on AMD's promises that it would be game changing as far as price to performance. It, just like the entire 50 series, has just made everything worse.

Sadly, I don't see things getting any better, and I guess I should pretend I was "lucky" to be able to buy a "Microcentre MSRP" 9070 XT at a mere 25% markup.
Funny thing is I don't feel lucky. For all that the card is certainly an improvement over what I'd had before I'd advise 90% of gamers to buy a 7800XT or 7900 GRE and be happy with 1440p, rather than spend twice as much on a card with 4k pretensions that can only really pull 4k 60fps without upscaling, and with upscaling the GRE or 7800 XT can still do basically exactly the same.

This card didn't move things forward. It moved it "sideways" at best. A 20% performance jump on a GRE for a 50% real world price increase is actually backsliding. No meaningful improvement over a 7900XT for a 30% price jump is also backsliding.

But AMD are not on their own in that, the 4070 Super is also a far better deal than the 5070 Ti or 5070, and the 4070 Ti Super was a better deal too..

This whole generation has been nothing but a great example of corporate greed, and no meaningful technological advancement. A wasted generation.

comments.text:
Not a fanboy of either company, I have a Astral 5090 and a Ryzen 9950x3D (I simply buy the best in tier product) with this said the 200k+ sales of the AMD cards in my opinion simply equates to the people who already would have bought an AMD card regardless. If Nvidia had more availability the numbers would be different.

Once again not bias or a fanboy, im the type of person who would never buy an AMD card regardless of the price to performance, the only time I would maybe consider AMD over Nvidia is if they had their Ryzen moment like they did against intel and the AMD gpu offered superior Raster and RT performance compared to the Nvidia GPU, which is most likely never going to happen in this life time (Nothings impossible however Nvidia have a never ending RND budget compared with AMD) other factors for me are Nvidia has the better driver suite, better DLSS and Upscaling tech, better re sale value and so on. 

I am not the only one who thinks like this as its evident in Nvidias vastly larger market share. Another factor is AMD in the last 8-10 years has not had a product to rival Nvidia on the high end, they had the 7970 and 7970ghz edition in 2013 which was a great rival against the GTX680, since then it was flop after flop either extremly hot cards, dual gpu carrds that ran hot and under performed or simply refresh after refresh until the RX series where we got the 6900xt and 6950xt which did very well against the 3090 and 3090ti in raster performance, AMD then gave us the 7900XTX which they lied about competing against the RTX4090 and now the 9700XT which only competes with both AMDs previous 7900xtx and RTX 4080s. AMD needs to compete at every price to performance bracket, people who simply want the best like I do where money isnt a problem have no choice but to go straight to NVIDIA. 

Anyway rant over, market share in this segment isn't a huge factor, AMD need to sell 2-4 gpus to make the sales and profit Nvidia do selling a single gpu. I want AMD to do better as this keeps prices lower and competition competitive.

comments.text:
When we start to get into $600-$700+ GPUs I start to care more about RT as this is the class where it starts to become much more viable, especially when DLSS4 let's you use performance or balanced mode almost all the time so even a 40/5070 can use RT. And I have to admit it's really nice that I can pop the .dll in and get it on every game I own with earlier DLSS implementations, where I can only upgrade a precious few to newer FSR models, and none to FSR4 when I don't have a 9070. When I already daily drive AMD and Nvidia these make me lean Nvidia.

But the big one that really kills AMD for me is VR. VR is still painful on AMD if you play a wide breadth of games. It will be fine for 1 title then the next will have vomit inducing 1% lows. Something I just don't experience when I swapped back to an even slower Nvidia card. I just don't feel AMD cares for optimizing for VR games compared to flat titles. Which is unacceptable when 29% of gamers own a VR headset and growing. Of course Nvidia has more software engineers, but the fact stands that I don't have similar issues with NV cards.

I don't want to buy Nvidia anymore because I hate supporting their anti-consumer shenanigans and ever increasing prices, but AMD's drivers in VR takes me back to my 7870ghz edition where performance was great but drivers were a minefield depending on the game. 

AMD: Stop putting VR users in the back seat when more people own a headset than you have marketshare.

comments.text:
The major issue both AMD/Nvidia has but AMD suffers from more is they don't force board partners to make much of any base MSRP models. Which given a choice the board partner would rather make a premium model and profit $250+ rather then $100 on each card.
The crazy part is these chip shortages have given Nvidia/AMD far more power over board partners, they could flat out make them sign contracts stating they would produce say at least 50% base MSRP models or simply not receive chips. When it comes down to making $100 a card or $0 they would take that contract.
The amount of good PR AMD would have received had even half the 9070/xt cards been the base MSRP models would have been insane considering Nvidia cards don't even exist and were even higher over MSRP.

comments.text: I've been using AMD gpu in the last 2 years and I can tell you that FSR support is not a big problem, because you can mod(optiscaler) it into almost any game(literally ctrl+c ctrl+v) that supports DLSS,FSR or XeSS except the games with anticheat system because they check the game files. So multiplayer games are the only problem and Throne and Liberty was the only game I missed FSR 3.1 support. The nvidia sponsored titles doesnt have a good FSR implementation and Cyberpunk is the biggest joke ever, but ofc you can mod FSR4 into Cyberpunk or Black Myth Wukong with no issue. Not as good as native support, but way better than FSR 3.1. I hate when companys doing things like this. Like Mcrosoft paying for the anticheat system developers so they do not support Linux. Gaming on linux would be way better. Imagine that Linux can handle the 9950X3D like it should and the non-X3D CCD is not sleeping while gaming, it is doing the background work as it should. So the 9950X3D is a monster in Linux.

comments.text: I don't think the 9000 series gonna last, the vram temps are just too high what I've seen, 90-100*C in practise. All amd cards since 6000 series run high, but this is another level close to very fast degradation, which I've witnessed with mined cards, especially 6800 over 100 samples from a miner where majority degraded and you can find a lot of broken ones for sale as well. Same happened with 3090 (gddr6x though). Symptoms are easy to catch with artifacting, you have to underclock, but within a few weeks that starts to artifact as well until the card is useless. On closer inspection, you can find burned marks under microscope. Something to be aware of. What immediately became clear is that those the 9070 series run at 2500mhz vs 2000mhz (6000 series). Would be nice if someone can do tests with -500mhz on vram and post results vs default (2500mhz) and overclocked. Planned obsolesce in some way if you think about it. Whilst much better value for raster vs Nvidia, those mid range cards are still overpriced 2x, especially with cheaper bom vs cheaper 7000 series...

comments.text: Buddy why on earth are your Hunt Showdown results so bad? I have a 9070XT Nitro and at ULTRA, I mean everything turned on out the wazoo not just "high" whatever settings you have I get 120FPS... at Ultra 1440p. Something is VERY wrong with your set up here even your 5070ti should be over that. I have over 2000 hours in Hunt Showdown, I HATE FSR and DLSS because at range I can't see anything so I don't use them. I'm very confused you've done something wrong there. Just for a reference, my old 2080ti at low settings 1440p would get 110FPS. The 9070XT is 100% faster in raster so now I can max the game out and get a similar frame rate. You've done something wrong here and need to test again. Also just to add insult to the injury, Hunt Showdown is a COMPETITIVE online shooter. No one in their right mind is using TAA, it makes everything at range, in a game where you are constantly shooting at range nearly impossible to see. Stop testing with TAA turned on. comments.text:
So while it would be good to have a competitive market. What is happening now is not that.

Why?

Because NVIDIA losing market share to AMD does not mean the market is more competitive if it is because NVIDIA have essentially abdicated from the market with no supply.

A healthy competitive market means prices drop and better quality products get released at better price points.

This is not that.


Exchanging one monopoly for essentially a different monopoly leader means prices stay high and value stays low. 

This what is happening right now. AMD has the monopoly of supply for new products,with NVIDIA effectively abandoning the discrete graphics market being able to supply negligible amounts of stock.

comments.text:
​@ Just bought a 5070 ti this very early morning! Due to chronic health problems I can't travel anymore so I chose to splurge my vacation money on a new GPU. I used to rock a i7 4770k + GTX 1080 for many years and upgraded to a Ryzen 5600x + 3070 at quite a bad time to do so. I feel like I might be repeating the silly mistake of overpaying for a 70 series card with no that much V ram again, but I don't care. This will be the first time I get to actually enjoy path tracing (and homebrew LLM's). 

I think your 1440 Ultrawide is a far better choice when it comes to immersion, graphics and performance. I can only dream of owning a Oled tv/monitor right now, as of purchasing the 5070 ti I am completely poor again :P.

I grew up on Morrowind btw, and subsequently played Oblivion and Skyrim. Quite recently I've also learned to absolutely fall in love with the Unity version of Daggerfall. In my humble opinion Oblivion is a far better RPG than Skyrim, when it comes to the story, interacting with the world, the immersion, and overall whimsy of it all. Now that it has updated assets and graphics I cannot wait  to get my hands on it again! I used to play the game on a laptop that could barely run it at 20 fps (lowest settings and then some.ini), so the contrast will be even greater than for most people :).

There is a cheaper (still official) version on fanatical btw. And I implore anyone to get the deluxe edition. As it just adds sooooo many things that add way too much to the game.

comments.text:
Regarding FSR4 support: OptiScale is easy to use and can inject FSR4 into nearly all DX12 games that support DLSS2-and-onward. Then you just use the DLSS controls inside the game. OptiScale is an open source project, so it's free of charge, free of "unintended side effects" and ad free. 

Yes, this means spending all of 20-30 seconds per game, but it all but nullifies Nvidia's advantage in the number of titles you can get quality upscaling in.
comments.author: @andersjjensen

comments.text:
Wanted to add that when I have had an extremely limited budget, my thoughts are "what can I cut out and play a game I like". The budget/poorish mindset is very different from what's promoted as "features, shininess, and thingamajigs". 

Things like HDR are a dream and you get the cheapest monitor you can. CPU is what can tide you over for a few years. Everything is like that, including eye candy.

It's become something of a strawman to compare RT or high res. This isn't an argument against your results, rather an argument for how people with hard limitations think. Alex over at Digital Foundry often does performance comparisons with an older PC with older CPU.

Sometimes it turns out that the new GPU isn't worth it because the CPU can't handle the driver overhead, so one vendor looks better. 

I realize it's hard testing lower end systems, but in these trying times a lot of us are just trying figure out what's a good upgrade for a system that's half crap. So if I could ask anything, it's could you benchmark old CPU and new GPU and old GPU and new CPU and try to see where we get crossover?

Everyone keeps saying AMD have sold more 9070/XT than all of the 50-series combined, but I work in the industry and this couldn’t be further from the truth, but then again, I consider a pre-order to be a sale, as it is indicative of customer demand.

AMD shipped more GPUs, but there is still way more demand for Nvidia as indicated my the number of sales of 50-series GPUs.

comments.text: You may disagree with this but it is just an opinion…. I feel like gaming and PC building in general has become more about chasing numbers rather than the actual gaming experience. I can understand why you may need all that performance in competitive online gaming but a freaking single player game? Why do you need more than 60 fps? As long as the game is not stuttering and not hindering your ability to play the game, you are perfectly fine even at 45 fps! Games feel unrealistic the “smoother” they go. And I am not sure why everybody here with an average 9-5 feels like they NEED to be constantly upgrading. Even I with 3 businesses feel like this is such a waste of money. You do you of course…. I am still an enthusiast so I understand. But man… I have been doing retro gaming since COVID, and let me tell ya… In those early days of 3D gaming, games were perfectly playable with the high end hardware at under 15, 30 to 60fps depending on the period. Back then companies were competing against each other by making great technology that enables and enhances the visual experience and not just performance numbers. Those old games were much more fun too. Back then you really wanted to play the freaking game even if that means running it with a SiS530! It’s all gone now…. My last two upgrades were Zen 1 and Rocket Lake. These PCs still do everything i need in a 27” screen. Don’t feel the need to upgrade because it has become tiresome to chase the stupid numbers, upgrade all the time and because there is nothing interesting out there in terms of gaming. It’s all pretty looks but zero substance. In my opinion it’s about budget. If you have a GPU budget of around 800$ I’d get the 5070ti if it’s for around 800$ it has worse price-performance value than the 9070XT but dlss 4 it’s undoubtedly down better than FS4 (it’s impressive that FS4 is now even sliiiightly better than dlss3 , but still not in the level of dlss 4) and available in much much muuuch more games.

Raytracing performance is not as far as before but there is still a big gap with good rt implementations.

Better feauture set in general, and about 10% faster raster performance in general across different benchmarks.

So if your budget is 600 I don’t think you should scrap another 200 for a 5070ti get the 9070XT, but if your budget was already 800$ to begin with, I do think the 5070ti is a more premium experience overall with more QOL features.


It’s not one of those cases where it’s like “I don’t care if it fits your budget, it’s a waste of money, get the 9070XT and save yourself 200$

Like for example someone thinking to get an i9 14900Ks for gaming instead of a 9800X3D, save yourself some money and get the cheaper 9800X3D.

Here it’s not like this, if you have the money for it, it’s definitely a nicer product

comments.text:
FWIW, here's my "I'm nobody in the gaming industry" recommendation for anyone building an all-new parts gaming today, March 20, 2025.  Give up on buying either of these cards.  Buy a Ryzen 7600 (~$185 US) and an RX 7600 (~$270 US) and put them on a decent B650 board (so you upgrade some day).  Play the back catalog.  Ignore the games your system can't play at FPS and settings you like.  That's right; just don't play them.  Your real friends will still be your friends, your dog will still think you're the best human ever, and your cat will still get in your way and leave hair on your keyboard.  

Always playing the latest releases has become an endless tail chase -- a trap.  Don't fall for it.  For every gamer who falls in, a dozen more wish they could.  What a silly way to act.

Should put the DRIVER version in there somewhere, my 5070ti ( clocked to 5080 speeds ) absolutely annihilates my 7900xtx in ALL the games as I play them ( which surprised me ), 4K highest FSR/DLSS the game will run using DLSS swapper/Quality ( except HD2 which is somehow still beats my 7900xtx to death ). 572.83 is the newest driver just released a few days ago and it did a lot for me as a new 5070ti owner, one thing you need to consider if your looking at AMD is we just went 4 months without an official driver update and when we finally GOT it, AMD released it for the 9070 and moved FSR4 to a DRIVER level toggle....your not gonna get day 1 drivers or in the case of Stalker 2, Nvidia released pre launch drivers with a new feature....AMD putting FSR4 behind a paywall, while there were NO updates to FSR3+ for existing owners simultaneously not being able to use the Adrenaline features for any of the day one titles I purchased is why I swapped...driver support is a HUGE benefit, Nvidia has had some snafu recently but its already lining out..they have put out 2 drivers this month, that is never gonna happen with AMD..there are still people in the forums trying to get Day Z to work. Most of the games I play lately seem to be UE5 and AMD has a known issue with UE5 when using DX12 especially with Global Illumination.....

comments.text:
Thank you for this!
I really don't mean a pedantic asshole so excuse me or ignore this following part:

The mean with the provided data is -4.8%.
If we correct for outliers by using IQR (since the data is skewed which aligns with expectations that the 5070ti should have the edge) the corrected mean becomes -5.27%.
If we instead assumed they should be about equal, so a normal distribution in differences and correct the data via standard deviation, only Rocket League would be an outlier and the mean would change to -5.6%.

Obviously this isnt quite as accurate as could be, technically this should be split between 2k/4k and also split between pure rasterization and ray tracing. For the average person only 2k (should) be relevant and as it stands, if you absolutely need RayTracing in your life you should (for now) always go nvidia.

Lastly, the difference in price obviously also plays a role. I bought the highest end version of the 9070XT (xfx mercury oc) for 870€ while the absolute lowest tier and cheapest possible 5070ti here would be 1000€ minimum so a 15% difference in price.

comments.text:
When you see a benchmark claiming that Alan Wake 2 is 5% faster on AMD, you have to be crazy to take those results seriously. I mean, who wants to play Alan Wake 2 without RTX? They even included Cyberpunk results without RTX! I’m not even talking about path tracing, which AMD cards can’t handle at all. I feel like I’m one of the only people pointing out that they don’t want to include RTX performance. RTX is available in at least half of the games they tested. It’s the technology for dynamic lighting, so you’d have to be out of your mind not to realize you need an RTX card unless you only play Counter-Strike or Assetto Corsa.

Is this some sort of hardware value signaling? Are YouTubers afraid to say that AMD isn’t that great? I was already shocked by their price-to-performance comparison, using AMD’s MSRP versus the real market price of the 5070 Ti. How can anyone believe that MSRP will remain stable when there’s so much tension in the mid to high-end segment of the market? When will people call these reviewers out? And I’m not just talking about Hardware Unboxed, but all those hardware YouTubers. What is going on here?

comments.text:
As of right now, I can’t buy either one of these cards at even close to MSRP. Honestly, I think both companies, and their board partners, need to investigated by the FTC for deceptive trade practices and bait and switch advertising and sales tactics. Frankly, the board partners are the bigger problem in this regard, but Nvidia and AMD should be setting more stringent pricing guidance (with reasonable IHV / board partner margins baked in). This is exactly what they aren’t doing, which is why eVGA left the business. At Nvidia and AMD base MSRP, the board partners don’t have sufficient margin, so what we end up with is intentionally restricted supply of MSRP (bait) products, combined with an increasing supply of higher-margin upsell products. The MSRP products become nearly impossible to buy, and customers are pushed up to the switch.

Specifically, where they’re running afoul of the law is that they’re failing to meet anticipated demand for the bait (MSRP) product without disclosing the bait’s limited availability in advertising and marketing. Furthermore, Nvidia especially, in conjunction with their board partners, are failing to stock MSRP in any sufficient quantities. To be clear, this isn’t just a scalping issue (which is a separate problem), the issue is the enabling of an intentional forced upsell that’s happening at ever increasing scale. It’s classic bait and switch. This behavior is what automakers and car dealers once colluded around that led to bait and switch legislation.

comments.text:
Fair video, though I'm not convinced the 15% discount AMD needs to have is warranted. No mention of features AMD has, that Nvidia doesn't have, either. Like Radeon Chill. 
Please please look into this tech in some future video, it can be really nice to help VRR flicker, and reduce power consumption in titles that have a high fluctuation in user input. Like RPG's, whereby you dont need 150 fps when standing in a conversation with an NPC for 5 minutes. 

The 15% however, does rely on a fairly generalized perspective on how much emphasis people put on Raytracing and upscaling, and this isn't helped by Nvidia having this much marketshare and implementing these techniques into games because of it. Lets not forget they have a habit of dropping support for these techniques as soon as the competition catches up or developers stop using it in favor of something else. The 15% heavily ties in with Nvidia's marketing.

comments.text:
I have the 9070 XT, actually the exact model that's featured in this video, the Sapphire PURE, and there has been no driver update since the card was released. So it couldn't have gotten better from AMD drivers. It could have gotten better from Windows updates, but I doubt it.
I think we should wait at least until the next driver update to see if and what's better.

I will say that there is an issue with my 9070 XT PURE a lot of 9070 XT cards. They are sometimes pushing 200 MHz more than they can on the core clock and this causes instability and crashes. Not uncommon at all. It's stupid that this is the way these cards are released. This is easily avoidable and what's sad and even more stupid is that it's unfixable atm! The reason being you currently can't control the core clock! So you can't lower it. How dumb.
I hope for them that this is fixed with the next driver update because this is ridiculous.

Other than that, I can say I am satisfied with the card. It runs cool and after they fix the issue with the jumping core clock you can squeeze even more performance after undervolting which is very nice and makes the card cooler and faster - WIN-WIN situation.

comments.text:
Well... another RT DLSS4 fanvideo. I wonder when the YT reviewers will understand that most gamers simply do not care about RT. 
I guess I just need to follow one of the reviewers, since it's all just the same anyways. 

I would love to see some real benchmarks that actually mean something, something that actually shows if it is worth it to upgrade to a newer GPU. 
A 4090 ti capped at 144 fps looks to be more efficient than a card with less maximum performance. 
But if it's true, we, as the viewers, will never know because we would have to buy 20 GPUs to compare the results. 

It would be really nice if you used real setups with sensible graphic settings and then compare the GPU performance, power draw and heat. who needs 300 FPS in any game? Most users have 144 / 165 Hz displays. So test the performance of these GPUs at that point. 
Can I play the game natively and reach the FPS with card x? 
Do I have to draw 300 W to have 144 fps in cyberpunk? 
Can I go down to 120 W with DLSS or FSR? 
If I use a 4070 vs a 5070 vs a 9070 (non-xt), how much better would it be compared to let's say a 6800 XT or 7800 XT in efficiency? 
These are relevant questions for me but I never get an answer to it.

comments.text:
@awebuser5914  We are still seeing good generational gains, it's just that nvidia is keeping them to the most expensive tier only. Which funnily enough is the segment where it's most difficult technologically to achieve those gains. They achieved the 4090 being 70% faster than 3090 for same price.  They achieved the 5090 being 30% faster than 4090 (with a price increase but that could be attributed to memory subsystem). 

Nvidia could totally have brought 30-70% improvements down across the stack for the lower models for the same price as previous gens in the 40-50 series, but they just arent because of segmentation and profit margin seeking, and people still buying them validating the strategy.
comments.author: @Lemard77

comments.text: @Collin_J  Back in 2023, a 6700 XT cost about the same as the 3060. But it has slightly better performance than the 3060 Ti. AMD had better price to performance across all categories with RDNA2 after RDNA3 launched, while RTX 30 series retained very high prices for the performance offered.
comments.author: @savagej4y241

comments.text: @Lemard77  "We are still seeing good generational gains..."  Ummm, no...  The 5090 "wins" by using an absolutely colossal die and (and Blackwell in general) fairly small optimizations.  The GB202 is very similar to the die used in the GB100 used in the datacenter products, so no, they are not "keeping anything back".  If you look at the transistor count and die sizes of the 5080 and lower, they are very similar to their predecessors and the incremental gains are quite modest.
comments.author: @awebuser5914

comments.text:
​ @awebuser5914  2080Ti was also a massive die to gain on the 1080Ti on the same family of node (12 vs 16nm).  My point is that while using same node family, they could have compensated by using bigger dies for each tier. Like it happened in the 28nm and 16nm era. Not all gains have to be because of node die shrink.

AMD did similarly going from Vega VII to RDNA 1 and 2, all these three generations were on the same node family, and they got really good gains. The 9070XT is 40% faster than the similarly specced 7800XT on same 5nm node family for the compute part.
comments.author: @Lemard77

comments.text: @Lemard77  "9070XT is 40% faster than the similarly specced 7800XT on same 5nm node..."  Simply because AMD was trailing badly with RDNA3 design and didn't implement large on-die caches like Lovelace.   RDNA4 "fixed" this and now more cache will have significantly diminishing returns in the future.
comments.author: @awebuser5914

comments.text: @heroicsquirrel3195  But thats the thing us gamers and pc enthusiasts are just a small % that even if we hold out it doesn't effect them because they make so much money from data centers and I wish that wasn't true but that's the direction we are heading it seems
comments.author: @tuvn.

comments.text:
@awebuser5914  uuh large caches were first implemented with RDNA2, Nvidia followed with Lovelace, and the 7800XT equals 6800XT with half it's cache size, the 6700XT even has 50% more cache than 7800XT and a good bit worse performance. 

These are also architectural features which do explain how you can achieve good generational gains besides node shrinks, so this doesnt counter my point.
comments.author: @Lemard77

comments.text: @tuvn.  scalpers sell to data centers?
comments.author: @heroicsquirrel3195

comments.text: @Lemard77  "7800XT equals 6800XT with half it's cache size..."  Oh God, please don't even bother...  The cache changes on RDNA3 were for the rather irrelevant L3 cache.  It's the massive jump in L2 cache that Lovelace leveraged to great effect.  RDNA4 doubled L2 cache sizes and the results were obvious.  The same effect was obvious with Raptor Lake L2 cache increases with significant performance bumps with no other significant architectural changes.
comments.author: @awebuser5914

comments.text:
While I appreciate the effort to compare these GPUs so extensively and to make sure everyone is making an informed decision when they choose to get either one, I am confused about some of the choices that were made.

Why did you choose to enable RT on some titles and not in others? For example, why is GTA V tested with RT on but Black Myth Wukong is tested with RT off? Wouldn't it be better to test both methods and then split the final charts with all the aggregate data?

As it stands, the charts such as 9:20 are somewhat murky because we're comparing the GPUs with different settings at different games. Black Myth Wukong would get a significantly worse score for AMD with RT on. GTAV would likely get a much better score with RT off. Someone that clicks the video and skips to the "Average" sections video would read -6% for Wukong and -29% for GTA V, (rightfully) assume they were tested under the same circumstances, and come out with a wrong perception of the head-to-head between them. I watched the video and now I'm having doubts about all the games that you didn't mention individually sadly.

I honestly believe we should be comparing either with RT always or always off, across the entire suite of games. It's a much more "apples to apples" comparison then. You would have 2 sets of charts at the end for the gamers that care and those that don't care about RT that much. As some games don't even have RT, you could also build a final chart "Maxed Out Settings" where you would include the RT results for the games that support it and add the games without RT as well.

As it stands, I believe this video deserves a do-over in some sections for a more comprehensive comparison across the suite of games you've chosen to benchmark.

@Sega-q6p Boo-hoo-hoo. Is your precious market milking, proprietary feature injecting trillion dollar conglomerate not in everyone's good graces any more? Sounds SO tough. Have a cookie and wipe your eyes.

Seriously, you sound exactly like the Intel noggins who refused to accept that the Ryzen 3600 was an absurdly good value product compared to both the 9600k and 10600k. Yes Intel was "winning" by small amounts, but the price they were asking for that little bit extra was simply not worth it for the vast majority of people. And the arguments became dumber and dumber. I legit saw one of them saying "The 10900k is the fastest gaming CPU in the world. That's why I'm buying a 10600k. I don't want to play on the losing team". The thing just is... if you're not buying the outright best, at whatever price that happens to be, you're already in the value equation. And value equations doesn't stop at the brand boundary. "Not the best" is "Not the best". And currently "the best" is the 9800X3D and the 5090. If you are not buying those, then you're in the game of maximizing the performance you can get within your budget. But "maximizing performance" is inherently about personal preferences for which trade-offs you can make to gain something else that is more important to you.

comments.text:
I don't get that sentiment. At MSRP it's 9% cheaper for 12% less performance. That's almost a rounding error. Normally the cost-per-frame goes down though the stack, but normally the VRAM ALSO goes down with it. This is a 16GB card. And it has good efficiency. 88% the performance for 72% the power. At linear cost-per-frame it should have been $528. $22 "extra" for not-12GB, good thermals, silence and efficiency is a deal some will find attractive and some won't. But universally calling it a "not recommended - spent $50 more on the XT" is both dumb and exactly what AMD wants reviewers to say.

A head to head, even at claimed MSRP, between the 9070 and 5070 is an absolute bloodbath for the 5070: 16GB vs 12GB, 220W vs 250W, "110FPS vs 100FPS" in raster and RT parity in all games that can hit 60FPS on either. I'm not going to pouting over "the missing $22" in that comparison.

comments.text:
Gamers beware - most people don't feel a difference after 240 Hz. Don't waste your money on more than 240 Hz. I just upgraded from 170 Hz IPS to a 360 Hz QD-OLED for my 7900 XTX + 9800X3D setup. Sure, I can max out the monitor with ease, but the difference is way smaller than I expected. There is a difference, it feels slightly better, but not 50% more GPU and CPU resources better, that's for sure. Unless you are a competitive CS/Valorant player, in which case you need 500 Hz, but you guys know who you are, so this doesn't apply to you. 

98% of people would be perfectly happy with either 240 Hz 1440p or 240 Hz 4K display, depending on how rich you are. Personally I wouldn't go below 144 Hz 1440p, especially when you can get an IPS monitor with those specs for pocket change these days. 
Say it with me - never 360 Hz, 240 Hz is good enough.

comments.author: @ayfr1249

comments.text:
@ayfr1249  My LG C2 is yet to have any visible burn in. I've been using it since it released in 2022. My colleague has C1 with no burn in too (1 year older). I've been using it as a PC screen and console screen since I bought it. The whole issue is vastly overblown in my opinion. As long as you don't buy first gen QD-OLED or abuse it for no reason the WOLED or 2nd or above gen QD-OLED would perform exceptionally well with no real burn in. Obviously, your screen has a lifespan and that sucks, but if you can afford changing your TV every 5-7 years (depending on usage), then you can definitely go for it. It's not for the poor people, it's a luxury technology after all. I'll probably upgrade my TV to a LG C8/G8. They are great, just a little expensive, but what can you do - that's the main downside of the good things. 
Sure, I understand your idea - my Philips LCD screen is 15 years old now. It looks awful, it's 1366x768, has terrible colors, 60 Hz refresh rate, but it works. This screen will outlive my LG C2, I am certain of it. But do I really want to use this 80 USD (in 2010 money) right now just because it works? Certainly not. The tech has a set lifespan - either by design or it's limited usefulness. Why would I use my old Athlon II just because it works? Sure, the CPUs can work 30 years non stop before they break, but I think I prefer my 9800X3D. LED/LCD screens have the same limitations. You might get a little more life out of them, but they become obsolete all the same. And if the price to pay for having the superior visual quality is to change my monitor/TV 3 years earlier than the rest, then I'd happily do it. Now seriously - how many of you are still using monitors that are more than 10 years old? I stopped using my Philips LCD around the 10 years mark. I'll probably stop using my LG C2 around the 7 years mark. It's not a big deal to me.

comments.text:
@ This has already been tested many times. Most people don't notice beyond even 120 unless they're looking at them side by side, let alone 240. I can tell up to around 180-200, but only if it's side by side with 120. Sitting alone I can barely tell above 150ish on a 240hz display. Beyond that I can't even tell side by side 240>360 even if I'm moving the mouse.

The hilarious part is when you get into the math and science. We've been studying the brain since long before competitive video games. It's a scientific fact that even the most superhuman brains can only react within 100ms, while they can perceive data at 10bits per ms. Vision is going to perceive at best at a 5ms rate, which is still a miniscule 50 bits of data or only 6 letters, let alone the number of bits to see and process a screen. Ironically 5ms is 200fps. Exactly where I stop seeing a difference.

Anything beyond that is a placebo effect. I'm sure there's some edge cases like professional players that have spent years honing their skills and senses, but they're still not going to react faster than a superhuman 100ms when 400ms is more realistic for the average person in a state of heightened sense. Anyone arguing about 360>240 is arguing over 1.4ms, and 500>360 0.7ms. Literally faster than the brain works, let alone your vision can perceive. And laughable when you account for mouse+monitor+internet latency when even the best hardware is still going to add at least 10ms, but more realistically 20+.

So you're right, 240hz IS good enough. More than good enough. Going above 240 is already on the edge of how fast even the fastest brain, let alone vision, can process data and this is those edge cases of professional players. 360>500 is literally scientifically impossible and entirely a placebo effect. 

Never underestimate the power of the placebo effect. If you took a 360hz and 500hz monitor, put them side by side but changed the labels, 10/10 people would either be honest and say they felt the same, or say the 360hz display felt smoother.

360hz is already deep in scam territory. 500 is a straight up lie to sell more profitable hardware.

comments.text: Absolutely not, I paid 969€ my 5070TI Asus Prime on Amazon while the Sapphire is sold 819€ here in France and 989€ on amazon if you wish to have it directly as it's sold out almost everywhere. In my case, beside gaming I also use a lot Solidworks and Adobe softwares which are way more optimized with NVIDIA than AMD (I just had a 7900XT before). 9 or 10 games I play often are DLSS compatible and DLSS, even in Balanced mod is way more qualitative than the Quality mod of FSR3 and even 4 according to recent pixel piping video comparing FSR3,4 vs DLSS 3 and 4. So,  comparing those 2 graphic cards, it's only 18% price difference for +6% raw performances and +26% with DLSS, adding the fact I used to have a lot of glitches and artifacts with my AMD 7900XT, some degraded performances on CAD Software, and struggling to have major slow down on Adobe LRC, PS and PP, for me it's a no brainer. For some one who plays only games that AMD is favoring, then yes, this card is a great choice, not on average, not for a wider use.

I'm coming from 7800XT and honestly if I knew that I'd like RT and knew that FSR is inferior to DLSS I'd probably opt for an Nvidia card at the time. Also I like the fact that it runs cooler, I hate when my room feels like a sauna during summer time. It comes down to affordability and priorities. If your main game requires only Raster then AMD is the better choice no doubt, but if you want a card that will potentially be able to run future RT games then Nvidia seems to be the choice.
